There is an emphasis on equity and how leadership understands and applies equitable and inclusive leadership practices.
29c1ff49-5579-4513-b097-8eeaa78ab5e5.name: Leadership in Governance

issuer.summary: issued by Grand Valley State University

badge_template_activities.title: The learner will complete Introduction to Board Service as a pre-requisite for this badge. This is a session offered by the Johnson Center 3 times per year. It is four hours in length. The requirement to earn the micro-credential includes completion and a score of at least 70% for the three, four-hour modules.

Workshop 1. Understanding how emotional intelligence shapes communication• Begin to identify bias and its impact on boardroom and organizational culture• Explore the complexity of identity and culture• Identify the key elements of inclusive leadership• Implement specific tools for leadership development
Workshop 2. Understand what it means to be a purpose driven board• Explore what sustainability means for nonprofit organizations• Identify the various types of resources a board manages
Workshop 3. How to run a board meeting• CEO relationship & evaluation• Staff relations• Board development & leadership succession• Navigating conflict in the boardroom

3a26f12e-9397-4d0a-9b26-d66ff9dd2eed.description: The badge is for leaders interested in developing a results-oriented management plan to lead organizations through uncertainties in the workplace. Badge earners developed a personal model of leadership behavior by examining one's own strengths, weaknesses and purpose and are able to identify strengths and gaps in building a high-performance team, make decisions to impact bottom-line financial results, drive results by optimizing organizational performance and lead organizational change.
3a26f12e-9397-4d0a-9b26-d66ff9dd2eed.name: Leadership Transformation

issuer.summary: issued by Grand Valley State University

alignments.name: The Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business
alignments.description: This program meets accreditation standards for the intersection of academic and professional engagement.

badge_template_activities.title: Module 1-Introduction to Becoming a Transformational Leader: Lead Yourself First: Topics include the connection between personality and leadership, overcoming leadership bias through the use of MBTI, how to lead others by first leading yourself and the the neuro-psychology of leadership.

Module 2-Building and Leading High-performance Teams: Topics include high-performing teams are RARE in workplaces...why?, what's broken and how do I fix it? and what's next?...developing an action plan.
Module 3-Understanding How Decisions Impact Bottom-line Financial Results: Topics include the principles of finance, learning the key tools in financial management and analyzing investment decisions.

Module 4-Driving Results by Optimizing Organizational Performance: Topics the challenges to establishing a culture for optimizing operational performance, the identification and applications of different approaches, tools, and techniques to optimizing operational performance, the importance and process of establishing a metrics that accurately measures operational performance over time.

Module 5-Leading and Managing Organizational Change and Complexities: Topics include differentiation between leading and managing, leading organizational change, the role of agility in organizational change and the importance of strategy in change initiatives.

dfc51633-eea4-4f4b-8592-b6146a70210a.description: The School of Computing's cybersecurity badge prepares students to identify, assess and address digital security threats. After completion students will be able to analyze risk using a variety of risk evaluation techniques, discuss legal and ethical issues related to information security and hacking, and use tools to secure networks. Students will learn how to develop frameworks for computer network forensics analysis, and apply tools and techniques for cyber-forensics.

4ede7607-9d4d-44a2-9a5a-b52bd22be9f5.description: This badge will prepare Program Officers at grantmaking institutions for conducting financial analyses and due diligence within the context of grantmaking activities. Earners are able to identify and apply criteria for financial health based on the profile of the program/grantee, recognize and apply various sources of financial information in the grantmaking process, analyze and synthesize project and organizational budgets and their component parts and effectively complete IRS Form 990.

alignments.description: This course may be used as continuing education towards accreditation by the American College of Financial Services for the Chartered Advisor in Philanthropy (CAP) designation.

badge_template_activities.title: The Financial Analysis Course includes curriculum, activities, materials and resources in topics including grant proposal review, project and operating budgeting, financial audits, financial statements and ratio analysis.

Two IRS Form 990 workshops follow a detailed presentation and include a variety of activities to promote learning and satisfy learning objectives that include understanding the Form 990 and its purpose, identifying key elements, investigating and analyzing a Form 990 through an equity lens, developing an understanding of Form 990 as an organizational tool and the information it communicates and understand the power of a Form 990 as a tool for the philanthropic sector.
Competencies of each course will be assessed using multiple choice questions, brief essays, quality of discussions and activities during the course and the completion of all course requirements.

f49f7a2f-80b1-44db-987e-f87079a558af.description: The badge prepares individuals to navigate the complex relationship between nonprofit boards of directors and executive staff in order to maximize organizational impact. Upon completion of the badge, earners can demonstrate strategies to insure legal compliance, financial sustainability and mission impact. Employing a racial and equity lens, earners will know the core and legal functions of a board, governance structures and how to overcome common challenges of a nonprofit board of directors.
f49f7a2f-80b1-44db-987e-f87079a558af.name: Nonprofit Sector: Nonprofit Board Service Leadership

issuer.summary: issued by Grand Valley State University

badge_template_activities.title: The 90 on 990 course introduces the badge earner to Form 990, it's purpose and the key elements of it. Earners will be able to use the form as an organizational tool, analyze information in Form 990 with an equity lens and realize the form's power as a data tool for the philanthropic sector.

The Introduction to Board Service course will develop an understanding of the core functions, legal and other responsibilities of a nonprofit board of directors. Earners will learn governance structures and how to apply them and identify common challenges and related strategies facing nonprofit boards.

The Board Leadership Cohort course will explain the key elements of developing and cultivating diverse boards of directors, analyze board structures and their impact as well as develop an understanding of the board's role in fund development.

The Transformations and Trends in Philanthropy course teaches the earner the significance of next gen donors and the rise of foundations choosing to not exist in perpetuity and identify new methods donors are utilizing. Earners explore how philanthropy is expanding globally and working to advance equity. They identify why practices to enhance equity and improving grantmaking by incorporating a racial equity lens are critical for increasing the effectiveness of Philanthropy.
